algorithms.name: Technical Architecture Group
algorithms.html:
The mission of the <dfn class="dfn-paneled has-dfn-panel" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-export="" data-lt="Technical Architecture Group|TAG" id="technical-architecture-group" role="button" aria-expanded="false" tabindex="0">TAG</dfn> is stewardship of the Web architecture.
	There are three aspects to this mission:

steps.html:
to document and build consensus around principles of Web architecture
			and to interpret and clarify these principles when necessary;
to resolve issues involving general Web architecture brought to the TAG;
to help coordinate cross-technology architecture developments inside and outside W3C.

algorithms.html:
If the number of votes to reject
	exceeds the number of votes to approve,
	the decision is overturned.
	In that case, there are the following possible next steps:

steps.html:
The proposal is returned for additional work,
			after which the applicable decision process is re-initiated.

algorithms.html: This document clearly indicates which information must be available to Members or the public, even though that information was initially communicated on Team-only or Member-only channels. Only the Team and parties authorized by the Team may change the level of confidentiality of this information. When doing so:

steps.html: The Team must use a version of the information that was expressly provided by the author for the new confidentiality level. In Calls for Review and other similar messages, the Team should remind recipients to provide such alternatives.
The Team must not attribute the version for the new confidentiality level to the author without the author’s consent.

If the author has not conveyed to the Team a version that is suitable for another confidentiality level, the Team may make available a version that reasonably communicates what is required, while respecting the original level of confidentiality, and without attribution to the original author.

algorithms.html: The Submission process consists of the following steps:

steps.html: One of the Submitters sends a request to the Team to acknowledge the Submission request. The Team and Submitter(s) communicate to ensure that the Member Submission is complete.

After review, the Team must either acknowledge or reject the Submission request.
  • If acknowledged, the Team must make the Member Submission available at the public W3C website, in addition to Team comments about the Member Submission.
  • If rejected, the Submitter(s) may initiate a Submission Appeal.
